template.template: Template Module Linux block devices by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Linux block devices by Zabbix agent

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk average queue size (avgqu-sz)
item_prototype.description: Current average disk queue, the number of requests outstanding on the disk at the time the performance data is collected.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request avg waiting time (r_await)
item_prototype.description: This formula contains two boolean expressions that evaluates to 1 or 0 in order to set calculated metric to zero and to avoid division by zero exception.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototype.description: r/s. The number (after merges) of read requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read time (rate)
item_prototype.description: Rate of total read time counter. Used in r_await calculation

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototype.description: This item is the percentage of elapsed time that the selected disk drive was busy servicing read or writes requests.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request avg waiting time (w_await)
item_prototype.description: This formula contains two boolean expressions that evaluates to 1 or 0 in order to set calculated metric to zero and to avoid division by zero exception.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototype.description: w/s. The number (after merges) of write requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write time (rate)
item_prototype.description: Rate of total write time counter. Used in w_await calculation

item_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Get stats
item_prototype.description: Get contents of /sys/block/{#DEVNAME}/stat for disk stats.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Linux block devices by Zabbix agent:vfs.dev.read.await[{#DEVNAME}].min(15m)} > {$VFS.DEV.READ.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} or {Template Module Linux block devices by Zabbix agent:vfs.dev.write.await[{#DEVNAME}].min(15m)} > {$VFS.DEV.WRITE.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read/write request responses are too high (read > {$VFS.DEV.READ.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m or write > {$VFS.DEV.WRITE.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m)
trigger_prototype.description: This trigger might indicate disk {#DEVNAME} saturation.

template.name: Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent

discovery_rule.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of file systems of different types.

trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left. As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left. As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Space utilization
item_prototype.description: Space utilization in % for {#FSNAME}

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Total space
item_prototype.description: Total space in Bytes

item_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Used space
item_prototype.description: Used storage in Bytes

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 5G. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<10G or {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)
trigger_prototype.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototype.description: Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}. Second condition should be one of the following: - The disk free space is less than 10G. - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

dependency.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
dependency.expression: {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].last()}>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and (({Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},total].last()}-{Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},used].last()})<5G or {Template Module Linux filesystems by Zabbix agent:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pused].timeleft(1h,,100)}<1d)

template.template: Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent
template.name: Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent
template.description:
Known Issues:
Description: High interface utilization trigger is removed since currently it is not possible to retrieve interface speed to determine the max bandwidth.
Template tooling version used: 0.38

discovery_rule.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Operational status
item_prototype.description: Indicates the interface RFC2863 operational state as a string. Possible values are:"unknown", "notpresent", "down", "lowerlayerdown", "testing","dormant", "up". Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
trigger_prototype.description:
This trigger expression works as follows: 1. Can be triggered if operations status is down. 2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down. 3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)
WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Interface type
item_prototype.description: Indicates the interface protocol type as a decimal value. See include/uapi/linux/if_arp.h for all possible values. Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].change()}<0 and {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].last()}>0 and ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].last()}=6 or {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].last()}=1) and ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}<>2)
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].change()}>0 and {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"].prev()}>0) or ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}=2)
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototype.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].diff()}=1)
dependency.recovery_expression: {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}<>2 or {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=0

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} or {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].min(5m)}>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:net.if.in["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8 and {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:net.if.out["{#IFNAME}",errors].max(5m)}<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototype.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High error rate (> {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)
trigger_prototype.description: Recovers when below 80% of {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} threshold

dependency.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
dependency.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and ({Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}=2 and {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].diff()}=1)
dependency.recovery_expression: {Template Module Linux network interfaces by Zabbix agent:vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"].last()}<>2 or {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=0

template.name: Template_DiskDrive_SMARTMONTOOLS_LLD
template.description: https://github.com/v-zhuravlev/zbx-smartctl 3.4 version with dependent items. Please check your UserParameters. Template version: v1.5

discovery_rule.name: smartctl-disks-discovery (HDD)
discovery_rule.description:
SMARTCTL_STATIC_DISKS - add additional disks in this macro with -d option. Replace all spaces with '_' inside each disk command. Separate multiple disks with space. For example, to discover 2 drives behind hardware RAID, set this macro on the host level:
SMARTCTL_STATIC_DISKS = /dev/sda_-d_sat+megaraid,00 /dev/sda_-d_sat+megaraid,01
Useful for disks that cannot be easily discovered such as disks hidden behind RAID or when agent is installed on Windows or Mac where automatic discovery is not so powerful.
Setting this macro doesn't prevent any automatic attempts to discover disks using smartctl --scan-open and so on.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: one or more SMART attributes are FAILING_NOW
trigger_prototype.description: Check test result output for details.

step.params: (?:SMART overall-health self-assessment test result:|SMART Health Status:) +\b([\S ]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: Disk has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Device serial number has changed. Ack to close

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 5 Reallocated sectors count
item_prototype.description: Count of reallocated sectors. The raw value represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped.Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This value is primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive; a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the immediate months. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes For SATA disks, mapped to 'ID 5 Reallocated Sectors Count' For Kingston disks, mapped to 'ID 5 Retired Block Count' For SAS disks, number of 'Elements in grown defect list' is used.

step.params: (?:5 Reallocate.+|5 Retired_Block_Count.+|Elements in grown defect list:)(?:[\t ]+)([0-9]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART Reallocated Sectors Count has been registered
trigger_prototype.description:
Count of reallocated sectors. The raw value represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped.Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This value is primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive; a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the immediate months.
Trigger: Timeouts in 7 days if there are no new reallocated sectors.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 197 Current pending sector count
item_prototype.description: SATA: ID 197 Current Pending Sector Count. Count of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped, because of unrecoverable read errors). If an unstable sector is subsequently read successfully, the sector is remapped and this value is decreased. Read errors on a sector will not remap the sector immediately (since the correct value cannot be read and so the value to remap is not known, and also it might become readable later); instead, the drive firmware remembers that the sector needs to be remapped, and will remap it the next time it's written. However, some drives will not immediately remap such sectors when written; instead the drive will first attempt to write to the problem sector and if the write operation is successful then the sector will be marked good (in this case, the "Reallocation Event Count" (0xC4) will not be increased). This is a serious shortcoming, for if such a drive contains marginal sectors that consistently fail only after some time has passed following a successful write operation, then the drive will never remap these problem sectors. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes SAS: Not supported.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART Current Pending Sector counter incremented
trigger_prototype.description:
Count of "unstable" sectors (waiting to be remapped, because of unrecoverable read errors). If an unstable sector is subsequently read successfully, the sector is remapped and this value is decreased. Read errors on a sector will not remap the sector immediately (since the correct value cannot be read and so the value to remap is not known, and also it might become readable later); instead, the drive firmware remembers that the sector needs to be remapped, and will remap it the next time it's written. However, some drives will not immediately remap such sectors when written; instead the drive will first attempt to write to the problem sector and if the write operation is successful then the sector will be marked good (in this case, the "Reallocation Event Count" (0xC4) will not be increased). This is a serious shortcoming, for if such a drive contains marginal sectors that consistently fail only after some time has passed following a successful write operation, then the drive will never remap these problem sectors.
Triiger: Timeouts in 3 days if ther are no new sectors

dependency.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART Reallocated Sectors Count has been registered

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 198 Uncorrectable errors count
item_prototype.description: SATA: ID 198 (Offline) Uncorrectable Sector Count. The total count of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes SAS: error counter log should be parsed with JS in Zabbix 4.2: read+write "Error counter log Errors Corrected by Total Correction Gigabytes Total ECC rereads/ errors algorithm processed uncorrected fast | delayed rewrites corrected invocations [10^9 bytes] errors read: 2242530 24029 1718309 2266559 30372 409777.659 0 write: 1685701 2629 5464 1688330 2636 35228.365 0 verify: 4400 2 2 4402 2 432.531 0". Should be added to SSD as well.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART (Offline) Uncorrectable Sector Count has been registered
trigger_prototype.description:
The total count of uncorrectable errors when reading/writing a sector. A rise in the value of this attribute indicates defects of the disk surface and/or problems in the mechanical subsystem.
Trigger: Timeouts in 7 days if there are no new reallocated sectors.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 9 Power on hours
item_prototype.description:
Count of hours in power-on state. The raw value of this attribute shows total count of hours (or minutes, or seconds, depending on manufacturer) in power-on state. "By default, the total expected lifetime of a hard disk in perfect condition is defined as 5 years (running every day and night on all days). This is equal to 1825 days in 24/7 mode or 43800 hours."
On some pre-2005 drives, this raw value may advance erratically and/or "wrap around" (reset to zero periodically). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes

step.params: (?:Power_On_Hours.+ |Accumulated power on time, hours:minutes |Power On Hours:.+ )([0-9]+) \1

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 10 Spin retry count
item_prototype.description: SATA: ID 10 Spin_Retry_Count. Count of retry of spin start attempts. This attribute stores a total count of the spin start attempts to reach the fully operational speed (under the condition that the first attempt was unsuccessful). An increase of this attribute value is a sign of problems in the hard disk mechanical subsystem.

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART Spin Retry Count has been registered
trigger_prototype.description: Spin retry event is logged each time the drive was unable to spin its platters up to the rated rotation speed in the due time. Spin-up attempt was aborted and retried. This typically indicates severe controller or bearing problem, but may be sometimes caused by power supply problems. Trigger: Timeouts in 7 days if there are no spin retry events.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 190/194 Temperature
item_prototype.description: Current drive temperature. SATA: Parses value from attribute ID 194 or ID 190. SAS: Supported NVMe: Supported

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 199 CRC error count
item_prototype.description: SATA: ID 199 CRC Error Count. The count of errors in data transfer via the interface cable as determined by ICRC (Interface Cyclic Redundancy Check). SAS: mapped to 'Non-medium error count' NVMe: mapped to 'Media and Data Integrity Errors'

step.params: (?:UDMA_CRC_Error|CRC_Error_Count|Non-medium error count:|Media and Data Integrity Errors:).+ ([0-9]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART UltraDMA CRC Error Count too high: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}. Check cable!
trigger_prototype.description:
Low value of this attribute typically indicates that something is wrong with the connectors and/or cables. Disk-to-host transfers are protected by CRC error detection code when Ultra-DMA 66 or 100 is used. So if the data gets garbled between the disk and the host machine, the receiving controller senses this and the retransmission is initiated. Such a situation is called "UDMA CRC error". Once the problem is rectified (typically by replacing a cable), the attribute value returns to the normal levels pretty quick.
Triger: Timeouts in 1 day if there are no new errors.

discovery_rule.description:
SMARTCTL_STATIC_DISKS - add additional disks in this macro with -d option. Replace all spaces with '_' inside each disk command. Separate multiple disks with space. For example, to discover 2 drives behind hardware RAID, set this macro on the host level:
SMARTCTL_STATIC_DISKS = /dev/sda_-d_sat+megaraid,00 /dev/sda_-d_sat+megaraid,01
Useful for disks that cannot be easily discovered such as disks hidden behind RAID or when agent is installed on Windows or Mac where automatic discovery is not so powerful.
Setting this macro doesn't prevent any automatic attempts to discover disks using smartctl --scan-open and so on.

step.params: (?:SMART overall-health self-assessment test result:|SMART Health Status:) +\b([\S ]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: Disk has been replaced (new serial number received)
trigger_prototype.description: Last value: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1}. Device serial number has changed. Ack to close

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 5 Reallocated sectors count
item_prototype.description:
Count of reallocated sectors. The raw value represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped.Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This value is primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive; a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the immediate months. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes
For SATA disks, mapped to 'ID 5 Reallocated Sectors Count' For Kingston disks, mapped to 'ID 5 Retired Block Count' For SAS disks, number of 'Elements in grown defect list' is used.

step.params: (?:5 Reallocate.+|5 Retired_Block_Count.+|Elements in grown defect list:)(?:[\t ]+)([0-9]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART Reallocated Sectors Count has been registered
trigger_prototype.description:
Count of reallocated sectors. The raw value represents a count of the bad sectors that have been found and remapped.Thus, the higher the attribute value, the more sectors the drive has had to reallocate. This value is primarily used as a metric of the life expectancy of the drive; a drive which has had any reallocations at all is significantly more likely to fail in the immediate months.
Trigger: Timeouts in 7 days if there are no new reallocated sectors.

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 9 Power on hours
item_prototype.description:
Count of hours in power-on state. The raw value of this attribute shows total count of hours (or minutes, or seconds, depending on manufacturer) in power-on state. "By default, the total expected lifetime of a hard disk in perfect condition is defined as 5 years (running every day and night on all days). This is equal to 1825 days in 24/7 mode or 43800 hours."
On some pre-2005 drives, this raw value may advance erratically and/or "wrap around" (reset to zero periodically). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.M.A.R.T.#Known_ATA_S.M.A.R.T._attributes

step.params: (?:Power_On_Hours.+ |Accumulated power on time, hours:minutes |Power On Hours:.+ )([0-9]+) \1

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 177/202/233 SSD wearout
item_prototype.description:
SATA: Multiple IDs are used, depending on the vendor: 177 Wear Leveling Count: "The Wear Leveling Count (WLC) SMART value gives us all the data we need. The current value stands for the remaining endurance of the drive in percentage, meaning that it starts from 100 and decreases linearly as the drive is written to. The raw WLC value counts the consumed P/E cycles, so if these two values are monitored while writing to the drive, sooner than later we will find the spot where the normalized value drops by one." http://www.anandtech.com/show/8239/update-on-samsung-850-pro-endurance-vnand-die-size
Number of erase/program cycles per block on average. This attribute is intended to be an indicator of imminent wear-out. Normalized Equation: 100 – ( 100 * Average Erase Count / NAND max rated number of erase cycles)
233 Media Wearout Indicator: Intel SSDs report a normalized value from 100, a new drive, to a minimum of 1. It decreases while the NAND erase cycles increase from 0 to the maximum-rated cycles. 202 Percent_Lifetime_Used: A value of 0% indicates that 100% of the expected lifetime has been used. SAS: 'Percentage used endurance indicator:' can be used, but it must inversed: 100%-used first. For that Zabbix 4.2 preprocessing is required. NVMe: 'Available Spare:' value is used, where 100% idicated new drive and 0% indicates that 100% of the expected lifetime has been used.

step.params: (?:(?:177 Wear_Leveling_Count|202 Percent_Lifetime_Used|202 Percent_Lifetime_Remain|230 Media_Wearout_Indicator|233 Media_Wearout_Indicator|231 SSD_Life_Left) +0x[0-9a-z]+|Available Spare:) +([0-9]+) \1

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 190/194 Temperature
item_prototype.description: Current drive temperature. SATA: Parses value from attribute ID 194 or ID 190. SAS: Supported NVMe: Supported

item_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: ID 199 CRC error count
item_prototype.description: SATA: ID 199 CRC Error Count. The count of errors in data transfer via the interface cable as determined by ICRC (Interface Cyclic Redundancy Check). SAS: mapped to 'Non-medium error count' NVMe: mapped to 'Media and Data Integrity Errors'

step.params: (?:UDMA_CRC_Error|CRC_Error_Count|Non-medium error count:|Media and Data Integrity Errors:).+ ([0-9]+) \1

trigger_prototype.name: {#DISKNAME}: SMART UltraDMA CRC Error Count too high: {ITEM.LASTVALUE}. Check cable!
trigger_prototype.description:
Low value of this attribute typically indicates that something is wrong with the connectors and/or cables. Disk-to-host transfers are protected by CRC error detection code when Ultra-DMA 66 or 100 is used. So if the data gets garbled between the disk and the host machine, the receiving controller senses this and the retransmission is initiated. Such a situation is called "UDMA CRC error". Once the problem is rectified (typically by replacing a cable), the attribute value returns to the normal levels pretty quick.
Triger: Timeouts in 1 day if there are no new errors.

item_prototype.name: Rank ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select attributes from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
SMBIOS - Type 17 - Attributes. Represents the RANK.
This value comes from the Attributes member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Bank ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select BankLabel from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Physically labeled bank where the memory is located.
Examples: "Bank 0", "Bank A"
This value comes from the Bank Locator member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Capacity ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Capacity from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Total capacity of the physical memory—in bytes.
This value comes from the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS version information. For SMBIOS versions 2.1 thru 2.6 the value comes from the Size member. For SMBIOS version 2.7+ the value comes from the Extended Size member.

item_prototype.name: Configured clock speed ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select ConfiguredClockSpeed from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The configured clock speed of the memory device, in megahertz (MHz), or 0, if the speed is unknown.
This value comes from the Configured Memory Clock Speed member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Configured voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select ConfiguredVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Configured voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Configured voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Module location ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select DeviceLocator from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
This value comes from the Device Locator member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Form factor ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FormFactor from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Implementation form factor for the chip.
This value comes from the Form Factor member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Manufacturer ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Manufacturer from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Name of the organization responsible for producing the physical element.
This value comes from the Manufacturer member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Max voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MaxVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The maximum operating voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Maximum voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Min voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MinVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The minimum operating voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Minimum voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Part number ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PartNumber from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Part number assigned by the organization responsible for producing or manufacturing the physical element.
This value comes from the Part Number member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Serial number ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select serialnumber from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Manufacturer-allocated number to identify the physical element.
This value comes from the Serial Number member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

trigger_prototype.name: Memory: module serial number has been changed ({HOST.IP})

item_prototype.name: Memory type ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SMBIOSMemoryType from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Type of physical memory. This is a CIM value that is mapped to the SMBIOS value. The SMBIOSMemoryType property contains the raw SMBIOS memory type.
This value comes from the Memory Type member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Max clock speed ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Speed from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Speed of the physical memory in nanoseconds.
This value comes from the Speed member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Architecture ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Architecture from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Processor architecture used by the platform.

item_prototype.name: Caption ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Caption from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: Current clock ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentClockSpeed from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Current speed of the processor, in MHz. This value comes from the Current Speed member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Current voltage ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentVoltage from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Voltage of the processor. If the eighth bit is set, bits 0-6 contain the voltage multiplied by 10. If the eighth bit is not set, then the bit setting in VoltageCaps represents the voltage value. CurrentVoltage is only set when SMBIOS designates a voltage value.

item_prototype.name: L2 cache size ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select L2CacheSize from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: L3 cache size ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select L3CacheSize from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: Max clock ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MaxClockSpeed from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Maximum speed of the processor, in MHz. This value comes from the Max Speed member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Name ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Name from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Label by which the object is known. When this property is a subclass, it can be overridden to be a key property. This value comes from the Processor Version member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Number of cores ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NumberOfCores from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Number of cores for the current instance of the processor. A core is a physical processor on the integrated circuit. For example, in a dual-core processor this property has a value of 2.

item_prototype.name: Number of logical cores ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NumberOfLogicalProcessors from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Number of logical processors for the current instance of the processor. For processors capable of hyperthreading, this value includes only the processors which have hyperthreading enabled.

item_prototype.name: Revision ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Revision from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
System revision level that depends on the architecture. The system revision level contains the same values as the Version property, but in a numerical format.

item_prototype.name: Virtualization fw ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select VirtualizationFirmwareEnabled from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
If True, the Firmware has enabled virtualization extensions. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista: This property is not supported before Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

item_prototype.name: Build number
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select buildnumber from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Build number of an operating system. It can be used for more precise version information than product release version numbers.
Example: "1381"

item_prototype.name: Caption
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select caption from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem

item_prototype.name: Code page ID (IBM)
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select codeset from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/intl/code-page-identifiers
Code page value an operating system uses. A code page contains a character table that an operating system uses to translate strings for different languages. The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) lists values that represent defined code pages. If an operating system does not use an ANSI code page, this member is set to 0 (zero). The CodeSet string can use a maximum of six characters to define the code page value.

item_prototype.name: Country code ID (IBM)
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select countrycode from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Code for the country/region that an operating system uses. Values are based on international phone dialing prefixes—also referred to as IBM country/region codes. This property can use a maximum of six characters to define the country/region code value.

item_prototype.name: Computer system name
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CSName from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem

item_prototype.name: Timezone GMT
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select currenttimezone from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in minutes, an operating system is offset from Greenwich mean time (GMT). The number is positive, negative, or zero.

item_prototype.name: Free physical memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select freephysicalmemory from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of physical memory currently unused and available

item_prototype.name: Free space in pagefile
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpaceInPagingFiles from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, that can be mapped into the operating system paging files without causing any other pages to be swapped out.

item_prototype.name: Free virtual memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeVirtualMemory from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

item_prototype.name: Install date
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select InstallDate from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

item_prototype.name: Last bootup time
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select LastBootUpTime from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
LastBootupTime property to determine how long the server has been active. The sample also uses the timeout option to ensure that the WMI call does not hang.

item_prototype.name: Local datetime
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select LocalDateTime from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Operating system version of the local date and time-of-day.

item_prototype.name: Manufacturer
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Manufacturer from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Name of the operating system manufacturer. For Windows-based systems, this value is "Microsoft Corporation".

item_prototype.name: Architecture
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select OSArchitecture from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Architecture of the operating system, as opposed to the processor. This property can be localized.

item_prototype.name: Serial number
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SerialNumber from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Operating system product serial identification number.
Example: "10497-OEM-0031416-71674"

item_prototype.name: System drive
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SystemDrive from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Letter of the disk drive on which the operating system resides. Example: "C:"

item_prototype.name: Total virtual memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select TotalVirtualMemorySize from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory.

item_prototype.name: Total visible memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select TotalVisibleMemorySize from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Total amount, in kilobytes, of physical memory available to the operating system.

item_prototype.name: Version
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Version from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Version number of the operating system.
Example: "4.0"

This value comes from the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS version information. For SMBIOS versions 2.1 thru 2.6 the value comes from the Size member. For SMBIOS version 2.7+ the value comes from the Extended Size member.

item_prototype.name: Configured clock speed ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select ConfiguredClockSpeed from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The configured clock speed of the memory device, in megahertz (MHz), or 0, if the speed is unknown.
This value comes from the Configured Memory Clock Speed member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Configured voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select ConfiguredVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Configured voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Configured voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Module location ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select DeviceLocator from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
This value comes from the Device Locator member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Form factor ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FormFactor from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Implementation form factor for the chip.
This value comes from the Form Factor member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Manufacturer ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Manufacturer from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Name of the organization responsible for producing the physical element.
This value comes from the Manufacturer member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Max voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MaxVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The maximum operating voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Maximum voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Min voltage ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MinVoltage from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
The minimum operating voltage for this device, in millivolts, or 0, if the voltage is unknown.
This value comes from the Minimum voltage member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Part number ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PartNumber from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Part number assigned by the organization responsible for producing or manufacturing the physical element.
This value comes from the Part Number member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Serial number ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select serialnumber from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Manufacturer-allocated number to identify the physical element.
This value comes from the Serial Number member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

trigger_prototype.name: Memory: module serial number has been changed ({HOST.IP})

item_prototype.name: Memory type ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SMBIOSMemoryType from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Type of physical memory. This is a CIM value that is mapped to the SMBIOS value. The SMBIOSMemoryType property contains the raw SMBIOS memory type.
This value comes from the Memory Type member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Max clock speed ({#SN})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Speed from Win32_PhysicalMemory where serialnumber='{#SN}' and tag='{#TAG}' ]
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-physicalmemory
Speed of the physical memory in nanoseconds.
This value comes from the Speed member of the Memory Device structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Architecture ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Architecture from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Processor architecture used by the platform.

item_prototype.name: Caption ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Caption from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: Current clock ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentClockSpeed from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Current speed of the processor, in MHz. This value comes from the Current Speed member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Current voltage ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentVoltage from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Voltage of the processor. If the eighth bit is set, bits 0-6 contain the voltage multiplied by 10. If the eighth bit is not set, then the bit setting in VoltageCaps represents the voltage value. CurrentVoltage is only set when SMBIOS designates a voltage value.

item_prototype.name: L2 cache size ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select L2CacheSize from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: L3 cache size ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select L3CacheSize from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor

item_prototype.name: Max clock ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MaxClockSpeed from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Maximum speed of the processor, in MHz. This value comes from the Max Speed member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Name ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Name from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Label by which the object is known. When this property is a subclass, it can be overridden to be a key property. This value comes from the Processor Version member of the Processor Information structure in the SMBIOS information.

item_prototype.name: Number of cores ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NumberOfCores from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Number of cores for the current instance of the processor. A core is a physical processor on the integrated circuit. For example, in a dual-core processor this property has a value of 2.

item_prototype.name: Number of logical cores ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NumberOfLogicalProcessors from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
Number of logical processors for the current instance of the processor. For processors capable of hyperthreading, this value includes only the processors which have hyperthreading enabled.

item_prototype.name: Revision ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Revision from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
System revision level that depends on the architecture. The system revision level contains the same values as the Version property, but in a numerical format.

item_prototype.name: Virtualization fw ({#DEVID})
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select VirtualizationFirmwareEnabled from Win32_Processor where DeviceID like '{#DEVID}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-processor
If True, the Firmware has enabled virtualization extensions. Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista: This property is not supported before Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

item_prototype.name: Build number
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select buildnumber from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Build number of an operating system. It can be used for more precise version information than product release version numbers.
Example: "1381"

item_prototype.name: Caption
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select caption from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem

item_prototype.name: Code page ID (IBM)
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select codeset from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/intl/code-page-identifiers
Code page value an operating system uses. A code page contains a character table that an operating system uses to translate strings for different languages. The American National Standards Institute (ANSI) lists values that represent defined code pages. If an operating system does not use an ANSI code page, this member is set to 0 (zero). The CodeSet string can use a maximum of six characters to define the code page value.

item_prototype.name: Country code ID (IBM)
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select countrycode from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Code for the country/region that an operating system uses. Values are based on international phone dialing prefixes—also referred to as IBM country/region codes. This property can use a maximum of six characters to define the country/region code value.

item_prototype.name: Computer system name
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CSName from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description: More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem

item_prototype.name: Timezone GMT
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select currenttimezone from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in minutes, an operating system is offset from Greenwich mean time (GMT). The number is positive, negative, or zero.

item_prototype.name: Free physical memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select freephysicalmemory from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of physical memory currently unused and available

item_prototype.name: Free space in pagefile
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpaceInPagingFiles from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, that can be mapped into the operating system paging files without causing any other pages to be swapped out.

item_prototype.name: Free virtual memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeVirtualMemory from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

item_prototype.name: Install date
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select InstallDate from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory currently unused and available.

item_prototype.name: Last bootup time
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select LastBootUpTime from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
LastBootupTime property to determine how long the server has been active. The sample also uses the timeout option to ensure that the WMI call does not hang.

item_prototype.name: Local datetime
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select LocalDateTime from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Operating system version of the local date and time-of-day.

item_prototype.name: Manufacturer
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Manufacturer from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Name of the operating system manufacturer. For Windows-based systems, this value is "Microsoft Corporation".

item_prototype.name: Architecture
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select OSArchitecture from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Architecture of the operating system, as opposed to the processor. This property can be localized.

item_prototype.name: Serial number
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SerialNumber from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Operating system product serial identification number.
Example: "10497-OEM-0031416-71674"

item_prototype.name: System drive
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select SystemDrive from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Letter of the disk drive on which the operating system resides. Example: "C:"

item_prototype.name: Total virtual memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select TotalVirtualMemorySize from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Number, in kilobytes, of virtual memory.

item_prototype.name: Total visible memory
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select TotalVisibleMemorySize from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Total amount, in kilobytes, of physical memory available to the operating system.

item_prototype.name: Version
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Version from Win32_OperatingSystem where CSname like '{#CSNAME}']
item_prototype.description:
More info -> https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/cimwin32prov/win32-operatingsystem
Version number of the operating system.
Example: "4.0"

trigger.name: CARP Status not Expected on {HOST.NAME}
trigger.description: pfSense CARP is not in the state Expected. This means that a failover could be in process.

trigger.expression: {Template Module Linux generic by Zabbix agent:proc.num.last()}/{Template Module Linux generic by Zabbix agent:kernel.maxproc.last()}*100>80
trigger.name: Getting closer to process limit (over 80% used)
High swap space usage ( less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)

trigger.expression: {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:system.swap.size[,pfree].min(5m)}<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:system.swap.size[,total].last()}>0
trigger.name: High swap space usage (less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
trigger.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured

dependency.name: Lack of available memory (< {$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})
dependency.expression: {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:vm.memory.size[available].min(5m)}<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:vm.memory.size[total].last()}>0

trigger.expression: {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:vm.memory.size[available].min(5m)}<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and {Template Module Linux memory by Zabbix agent:vm.memory.size[total].last()}>0
trigger.name: Lack of available memory (< {$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})
Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Per CPU load average is too high. Your system may be slow to respond.

trigger.name: Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
trigger.description: Per CPU load average is too high. Your system may be slow to respond.

trigger.name: New Version Available on {HOST.NAME}
trigger.description: Noify of new version of pfsense available

({Template_Magaz_Prisma:service.info[MSSQLSERVER].last()}<>0 and {Template_Magaz_Prisma:service.info[MSSQLSERVER].last()}<>255 and {Template_Magaz_Prisma:service.info[MySQL].last()}=255 and {Template_Magaz_Prisma:service.info[postgresql-9.4].last()}=255)
or
